content.description:
This is under rated and under climbed. Quality thin technical crack right of the ground. Little tricky small gear placements and then gets easier. Last 30 feet are in a big easy left facing corner. Climbing this allows a TR to be set up on Nahoul Wall.

Great warm up
content.protection: small gear at bottom. a number 2 and 3 camalot for the top
content.location: right of Nahoul wall and immediately west of Phantom Wall
This is the formation (not really named) that is immediately west of Phantom Wall

content.description: This is the clean face to the right of Dr. Jeckel and Mr. Hyde.  It shares the start (and crux) of Jeckel and Hyde but at the third bolt move right following easier runout terrain and old bolts.
content.protection: 7 draws. Optional knob tie off at the top.  The anchor is hand sized pieces or two old bolts (same anchor as the climbs to the left).
content.location: Start is the same as for Dr. Jeckel and Mr. Hyde.

content.description: Stellar mixed bolt and gear route.  Step off the ground and climb up and right through the undercling crux (protected by one bolt).  Pull out onto the arete and climb a thin tips crack (5.9) to a bolted anchor.  You can toprope this climb, but you may need to extend the anchor a bit to do it with a 60m rope.
content.protection: Bring thin nuts and cams (all the way down to BD 0.1 equiv.)  The crux 11c section is protected by a good bolt and you can place a big nut above your head before committing to pulling onto the arete.  You need small gear for the beginning of the crack, but the gear gets bigger the higher you go.  Gear to 3 inches.
content.location: Starts at the toe of the wall where the east facing slab intersects with the south facing vertical wall.

climbs.name: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
climbs.fa: Tom Smith, Krista Smith, Larry Von Wald, 1984

content.description:
Start on the slab south face of the Phantom Wall. Pull onto the slab and make delicate face moves with slopey knobs for feet and long reaches. Clip two bolts before making a long reach left to gain the thin, tips crack. Note that there are two bolts right next to each other at the second bolt - a buttonhead and a newer 3/8". Avoid clipping the third bolt - this will lead to rope drag up higher (the third bolt is for the adjacent face route Eraserhead (5.11c).

Climb the tips crack as it gradually gives good locks, and knobs appear for alternative holds. Once this crack peters out, place a piece and make a face traverse left to gain the fist crack. Follow this left crack to the top and finish by pulling a small roof.

There is an older two bolt anchor on top of the formation, but no rap rings. Descend by bushwhacking down a steep gully to climber's right.
content.protection: Gear micro cams/nuts to 3". Draws and at least one sling for the traverse.
content.location: South face of the Phantom Wall, east of the Lower Spire.
